questions.question_text: Define measurement in physics.
questions.key_concept: Measurement is the process of comparison of the given physical quantity with the known standard quantity of the same nature.
questions.expected_answer: comparison

questions.question_text: Which two parameters are required to express the result of a measurement?
questions.key_concept: The result is expressed in terms of the unit and the numerical value.
questions.expected_answer: Unit and Numerical value

questions.question_text: If the size of the unit chosen for measurement is smaller, how does the numerical value of the quantity change?
questions.key_concept: The numerical value expresses how many times the unit is contained in the quantity. Smaller unit implies larger numerical value.
questions.expected_answer: It increases

questions.question_text: If a piece of cloth measures 10 metres, what does the number 10 represent in this context?
questions.key_concept: The numerical value expresses how many times the selected unit is contained in the given quantity.
questions.expected_answer: The number of times the unit metre is contained in the length

questions.question_text: Distinguish between a fundamental unit and a derived unit.
questions.key_concept: Fundamental units are independent; Derived units depend on fundamental units.
questions.expected_answer: Fundamental units are independent of other units, while derived units are expressed in terms of fundamental units.

questions.question_text: Why must a standard unit be reproducible?
questions.key_concept: Essential properties of a unit include reproducibility for acceptance.
questions.expected_answer: So that it can be accepted internationally and copies can be made easily.

questions.question_text: What does the S.I. system stand for?
questions.key_concept: Systeme Internationale d'Unites
questions.expected_answer: Systeme Internationale d'Unites

questions.question_text: Identify the fundamental unit of mass in the F.P.S. system.
questions.key_concept: F.P.S stands for Foot, Pound, Second.
questions.expected_answer: Pound

questions.question_text: Is the 'litre' a fundamental unit in the S.I. system?
questions.key_concept: Fundamental units are Mass, Length, Time, Temp, Current, Amount of substance, Luminous intensity.
questions.expected_answer: No, it is not one of the seven fundamental units.

questions.question_text: Convert the prefix 'micro' to its power of 10 representation.
questions.key_concept: Prefix micro symbol is µ and factor is 10^-6.

questions.question_text: Compare the C.G.S. and M.K.S. systems regarding the unit of length.
questions.key_concept: CGS uses centimetre; MKS uses metre.
questions.expected_answer: C.G.S. uses centimetre while M.K.S. uses metre.

questions.question_text: Why are C.G.S. and F.P.S. systems considered of historical importance only?
questions.key_concept: S.I. system is the enlarged and modified version now used.
questions.expected_answer: They are no longer in standard international use, having been replaced by the S.I. system.

questions.question_text: Define one light year.
questions.key_concept: Distance travelled by light in vacuum in one year.
questions.expected_answer: The distance travelled by light in vacuum in one year

questions.question_text: Identify the unit used for measuring the size of a nucleus.
questions.key_concept: Fermi is used for nucleus size (10^-15 m).
questions.expected_answer: Fermi (f)

questions.question_text: Which is larger: 1 Parsec or 1 Light Year?
questions.key_concept: 1 Parsec = 3.26 Light Years.
questions.expected_answer: 1 Parsec

questions.question_text: Calculate the value of 1 nanometre in metres.
questions.key_concept: Nano means 10^-9.

questions.question_text: Compare the Astronomical Unit (A.U.) and the Light Year based on their definitions.
questions.key_concept: A.U. is mean distance earth-sun; LY is distance light travels in a year.
questions.expected_answer: A.U. is the mean distance between earth and sun, while Light Year is the distance light travels in a year.

questions.question_text: Why is the Angstrom (Å) considered outdated compared to the nanometre (nm)?
questions.key_concept: Preference for nm in modern science.
questions.expected_answer: Nanometre is a preferred S.I. sub-unit, whereas Angstrom is a non-S.I. unit.

questions.question_text: Define one mean solar day.
questions.key_concept: Time taken by earth to complete one rotation on its axis.
questions.expected_answer: The time taken by the earth to complete one rotation on its own axis

questions.question_text: Identify the unit used to express the mass of atomic particles like protons.
questions.key_concept: Atomic mass unit (amu) or unified atomic mass unit (u).
questions.expected_answer: atomic mass unit (a.m.u) or u

questions.question_text: Is a leap year strictly every 4th year without exception?
questions.key_concept: Century years are leap years only if divisible by 400.
questions.expected_answer: No, century years are leap years only if divisible by 400.

questions.question_text: How many seconds constitute one hour?
questions.key_concept: 1 hour = 60 min * 60 sec.

questions.question_text: Compare a 'Solar Day' and a 'Sidereal Day' is not in text, instead compare 'Lunar Month' and 'Month'.
questions.key_concept: Lunar month based on moon phases (29.5 days); Month approx 30 days.
questions.expected_answer: A lunar month is based on moon's phases (approx 29.5 days), while a standard month is approx 30 days.

questions.question_text: Why was the definition of the second changed from mean solar day to atomic time?
questions.key_concept: Mean solar day varies over years.
questions.expected_answer: Because the mean solar day varies over the years, lacking necessary precision.

questions.question_text: What is the derived unit of force?
questions.key_concept: Newton is the unit of force.
questions.expected_answer: newton

questions.question_text: Identify the correct way to write the symbol for the unit of force named after Newton.
questions.key_concept: Symbol named after scientist is capitalized (N). Full name is lowercase (newton).
questions.expected_answer: N

questions.question_text: Which is the correct written form for 10 kilograms: '10 kgs' or '10 kg'?
questions.key_concept: Unit symbols are never written in plural.
questions.expected_answer: 10 kg

questions.question_text: Derive the unit of Pressure in terms of fundamental units.
questions.key_concept: Pressure = Force/Area = (kg m s^-2) / m^2.
questions.expected_answer: kg m^-1 s^-2

questions.question_text: Compare the formatting of units named after scientists versus those that are not.
questions.key_concept: Capitalized symbol for scientist names; lowercase for others.
questions.expected_answer: Symbols for units named after scientists are capitalized, whereas others are lowercase.

questions.question_text: Why must we write 'newton' with a small 'n' but 'N' with a capital letter?
questions.key_concept: Convention: Full name lowercase, Symbol uppercase if named after person.
questions.expected_answer: Convention dictates full unit names are lowercase, while symbols named after scientists are capitalized.

questions.question_text: Define the least count of an instrument.
questions.key_concept: Smallest measurement that can be taken.
questions.expected_answer: The smallest measurement that can be taken with the instrument

questions.question_text: Identify the least count of a standard metre rule.
questions.key_concept: 1 mm or 0.1 cm.
questions.expected_answer: 1 mm

questions.question_text: If Instrument A has a Least Count of 0.1 cm and Instrument B has 0.01 cm, which is less precise?
questions.key_concept: Smaller least count = More precise. Larger least count = Less precise.
questions.expected_answer: Instrument A

questions.question_text: A stop watch has 10 divisions between 0 and 5s. Calculate its least count.
questions.key_concept: 5s / 10 divisions = 0.5s.

questions.question_text: Compare accuracy and least count.
questions.key_concept: Inverse relationship. Smaller LC leads to better accuracy.
questions.expected_answer: Decreasing the least count leads to an increase in accuracy.

questions.question_text: Why can a metre rule not measure correct up to the second decimal place of a centimetre?
questions.key_concept: Limitation of division size (1mm).
questions.expected_answer: Because its smallest division is 1 mm (0.1 cm), limiting precision to one decimal place.

questions.question_text: What is the 'vernier constant'?
questions.key_concept: Another name for Least Count of vernier.
questions.expected_answer: The least count of the vernier

questions.question_text: Identify the part of the vernier callipers used to measure the depth of a beaker.
questions.key_concept: Strip T.
questions.expected_answer: Strip

questions.question_text: When calculating the total reading, do you subtract the negative zero error or add it?
questions.key_concept: Zero error is always subtracted. Subtracting a negative becomes addition.
questions.expected_answer: Subtracting negative error (effectively adding)

questions.question_text: If 10 vernier divisions equal 9 main scale divisions (1mm each), calculate the least count.
questions.key_concept: LC = 1 MSD - 1 VSD or MSD/n. 1mm/10 = 0.1mm.
questions.expected_answer: 0.1 mm or 0.01 cm

questions.question_text: Compare positive and negative zero error in a vernier callipers.
questions.key_concept: Positive: Zero of vernier to right. Negative: Zero of vernier to left.
questions.expected_answer: Positive error occurs if vernier zero is to the right of main zero; negative if to the left.

questions.question_text: Why are the upper jaws (inside jaws) of a vernier callipers used?
questions.key_concept: Function of inside jaws.
questions.expected_answer: To measure the internal diameter of a hollow cylinder or pipe.

questions.question_text: Define the 'pitch' of a screw gauge.
questions.key_concept: Linear distance moved in one rotation.
questions.expected_answer: The linear distance moved by the screw in one complete rotation

questions.question_text: Which part of the screw gauge is used to hold the object gently to avoid crushing it?
questions.key_concept: Ratchet prevents overtightening.
questions.expected_answer: Ratchet

questions.question_text: If the zero of the circular scale is 'above' the base line, is the zero error positive or negative?
questions.key_concept: Above baseline = Negative error. Below baseline = Positive error.
questions.expected_answer: Negative

questions.question_text: Calculate the least count of a screw gauge with a pitch of 1 mm and 100 divisions on the circular scale.
questions.key_concept: LC = Pitch / Total Divisions. 1mm / 100.

questions.question_text: Compare a Screw Gauge and a Vernier Callipers regarding precision.
questions.key_concept: Screw gauge usually has smaller LC (0.01mm or 0.001cm) vs Vernier (0.1mm or 0.01cm).
questions.expected_answer: A screw gauge is generally more precise (LC 0.001 cm) than a vernier callipers (LC 0.01 cm).

questions.question_text: What causes backlash error in a screw gauge?
questions.key_concept: Wear and tear of threads.
questions.expected_answer: Wear and tear of the screw threads causing loose fit.

questions.question_text: Define the 'frequency' of oscillation of a simple pendulum.
questions.key_concept: Number of oscillations in one second.
questions.expected_answer: The number of oscillations made in one second

questions.question_text: Identify the relationship between time period (T) and frequency (f).
questions.key_concept: Reciprocal relationship.
questions.expected_answer: f = 1/T

questions.question_text: Does the time period of a simple pendulum depend on the mass of the bob?
questions.key_concept: Independence of mass.
questions.expected_answer: No, it is independent of mass.

questions.question_text: If the length of a pendulum is made 4 times its original length, how does the time period change?
questions.key_concept: T is proportional to square root of l. sqrt(4) = 2.
questions.expected_answer: It becomes double

questions.question_text: Compare the behavior of a pendulum clock in summer versus winter.
questions.key_concept: Expansion in summer increases length (slows down). Contraction in winter decreases length (speeds up).
questions.expected_answer: In summer, length increases and clock goes slow; in winter, length decreases and clock goes fast.

questions.question_text: Why does the slope of the T² vs l graph allow us to determine 'g'?
questions.key_concept: Slope = 4π²/g.
questions.expected_answer: Because the slope is equal to 4π²/g, which is a constant containing g.

questions.question_text: Define a Seconds' Pendulum.
questions.key_concept: Pendulum with time period of 2 seconds.
questions.expected_answer: A pendulum with a time period of oscillation equal to two seconds

questions.question_text: What is the approximate effective length of a seconds' pendulum on earth?
questions.key_concept: Nearly 1 metre.
questions.expected_answer: Nearly 1 metre

questions.question_text: A seconds' pendulum takes 1 second to move from one extreme to the other. What is its frequency?
questions.expected_answer: 0.5 Hz

questions.question_text: Calculate the length of a seconds' pendulum where g = 9.8 m/s² (use π² ≈ 9.8 for estimation).
questions.expected_answer: 0.994 m or approx 1 m

questions.question_text: Compare the frequency of a seconds' pendulum with a pendulum having T = 1s.
questions.key_concept: Seconds pendulum f = 0.5. Other f = 1.
questions.expected_answer: Seconds' pendulum frequency is 0.5 Hz, while the other is 1 Hz.

questions.question_text: Why is the time period of a seconds' pendulum 2 seconds and not 1 second?
questions.key_concept: 1s is time for extreme to extreme, T is complete oscillation (to and fro).
questions.expected_answer: Because it takes 1 second to move from one extreme to the other, so the return trip makes the total period 2 seconds.
